fae0847
Adding this checked Exception will require another PR to add try/catch blocks to MSAL so keep an eye out for that once this merges
replies.author: iambmelt

timeline.bodyText:
OK, this is your tricky synchronization part using concurrentMap.  You don't want to risk overwriting a concurrent writer without synchronizing this entire method.  So you make the result future and it's empty.  You then putIfAbsent into the sExecutingCommandMap.  If it returns null, then it did not populate the map and you add your listener to the future that you created since it was added to the map.  If it returns non-null, then you lost the race and you need add a listener to that future and return, since the command is already running.
You mainly run the get first because a get in the map is far cheaper than a putIfAbsent.
timeline.author: AdamBJohnsonx

replies.bodyText:
If it returns null, then it did not populate the map and you add your listener to the future that you created since it was added to the map. If it returns non-null, then you lost the race and you need add a listener to that future and return, since the command is already running.

This seems backwards -- wouldn't returning null indicate that I did win? Looking at:
https://developer.android.com/reference/java/util/concurrent/ConcurrentHashMap?hl=en#putIfAbsent(K,%20V)
replies.author: iambmelt

replies.bodyText: You're right.  And my statement was internally inconsistent, even.  If it returns null, it did populate the map and you add the callback to the future that you created and start execution.  If it returns non-null, add and return.
replies.author: AdamBJohnsonx

replies.bodyText: Think we're saying the same thing?
replies.author: iambmelt

replies.bodyText: Ah gotcha
replies.author: iambmelt

replies.bodyText:
Think we're saying the same thing?

Yes.  I'm trying to agree. ;-)
replies.author: AdamBJohnsonx

replies.bodyText: @AdamBJohnsonx Pushed changes in 98528c6 -- can you spot check me on this commit?
replies.author: iambmelt

timeline.bodyText: Well, do we?  Long term, it's a better way of communicating error states.  The contract here is that either you have a result or you have a throwable.  Mostly, the code for these looks like if (t == null) { error handling; return; } result handling;
timeline.author: AdamBJohnsonx

replies.bodyText: Applied in 91ed0a7
replies.author: iambmelt

timeline.bodyText: Hm.  OK, so we might want to pass in this executor to whenComplete.  As you may notice, in the event of a complete request, we're going to run the call back on whatever the current thread is running on.  If that's OK, it's more straightforward.  But if we want our callback to run on the silentExecutor thread in the event that the result is already completed by the time we attempt to run it, we probably want to pass this executor into whenComplete to use in the event we hit that case.
timeline.author: AdamBJohnsonx

replies.bodyText: Correct me if I'm wrong here.... I think we want to leave as-is, as calling back on the silentExecutor would be a threading behavioral change
replies.author: iambmelt

replies.bodyText: returnCommandResult is called by the runnable that was submitted previously, I thought.  Unless it has a way to transfer back to the calling thread, which I don't see, we currently call back from that executor.
replies.author: AdamBJohnsonx

replies.bodyText:
It posts back on the Handler created at ~L94 see:
https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-authentication-library-common-for-android/blob/iambmelt/command-sub-fix-905-redux/common/src/main/java/com/microsoft/identity/common/internal/controllers/CommandDispatcher.java#L230
replies.author: iambmelt

replies.bodyText: Wild.  OK, then it doesn't matter. Good - it's simpler like this.
replies.author: AdamBJohnsonx
